question_text: Which part of the Indian Constitution contains the Directive Principles of State Policy?
answer_explanation_text: The Directive Principles of State Policy are contained in Part IV of the Indian Constitution. These principles reflect a mix of humanitarian socialist precepts, Gandhian ideals, and democratic socialism.

question_text: Which article defines the term  <q>state</q> as in Part III of the Indian Constitution?
answer_explanation_text: Article 36 defines the term <q>state</q>as in Part III of the Indian Constitution. It is important to understand the meaning of the term  <q>state</q> to comprehend the scope and applicability of the Directive Principles of State Policy.

question_text: Which article states that the provisions of Part IV shall not be enforceable by any court?
answer_explanation_text: Article 37 of the Indian Constitution states that the provisions of Part IV shall not be enforceable by any court. However, these principles are fundamental in the governance of the country, and it is the duty of the State to apply these principles in making laws.

question_text: Which article requires the State to make effective provisions for securing the right to work, to education, and to public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness, and disablement?
answer_explanation_text: Article 41 of the Indian Constitution requires the State to make effective provisions for securing the right to work, to education, and to public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness, and disablement, and in other cases of undeserved want.

question_text: Which article directs the State to secure, to all workers, a living wage and conditions of work ensuring a decent standard of life and full enjoyment of leisure and social and cultural opportunities?
answer_explanation_text: Article 43 of the Indian Constitution directs the State to secure, to all workers, a living wage and conditions of work ensuring a decent standard of life and full enjoyment of leisure and social and cultural opportunities.

question_text: Which article requires the State to secure for citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India?
answer_explanation_text: Article 44 of the Indian Constitution requires the State to secure for citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India. This uniform civil code would apply to all citizens irrespective of their religion or personal law.

question_text: Which article directs the State to provide free and compulsory education for all children up to the age of fourteen years?
answer_explanation_text: Article 45 of the Indian Constitution directs the State to provide free and compulsory education for all children up to the age of fourteen years. This directive is aimed at ensuring that every child in India has access to quality education.

question_text: Which article requires the State to promote educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, particularly the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes?
answer_explanation_text: Article 46 of the Indian Constitution requires the State to promote educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, particularly the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes, and protect them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.

question_text: Which article directs the State to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living and to improve public health?
answer_explanation_text: Article 47 of the Indian Constitution directs the State to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living and to improve public health. This directive emphasizes the need for a healthy population for the overall development of the country.

question_text: Which article directs the State to organize agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines and prohibit the slaughter of cows and calves and other milch and draught cattle?
answer_explanation_text: Article 48 of the Indian Constitution directs the State to organize agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines and prohibit the slaughter of cows and calves and other milch and draught cattle. This directive aims at promoting sustainable agricultural practices and animal husbandry.

question_text: Which article directs the State to protect and improve the environment and safeguard the forests and wildlife of the country?
answer_explanation_text: Article 48-A, added by the 42nd Amendment, directs the State to protect and improve the environment and safeguard the forests and wildlife of the country. This directive highlights the importance of environmental conservation and protection of biodiversity.

question_text: Which article directs the State to protect monuments and places and objects of national importance from spoliation, disfigurement, destruction, removal, disposal, or export?
answer_explanation_text: Article 49 of the Indian Constitution directs the State to protect monuments and places and objects of national importance from spoliation, disfigurement, destruction, removal, disposal, or export. This directive emphasizes the need to preserve and protect the cultural heritage of the country.

question_text: Which article directs the State to take steps for the separation of judiciary from the executive?
answer_explanation_text: Article 50 of the Indian Constitution directs the State to take steps for the separation of judiciary from the executive. This directive is aimed at ensuring the independence of the judiciary and preventing any undue influence of the executive on the functioning of the judiciary.

question_text: Which article directs the State to promote international peace and security and maintain just and honorable relations between nations?
answer_explanation_text: Article 51 of the Indian Constitution directs the State to promote international peace and security, maintain just and honorable relations between nations, foster respect for international law and treaty obligations, and encourage the settlement of international disputes by arbitration. This directive reflects India's commitment to promoting global peace and harmony.

question_text: Which of the following is not a classification of Directive Principles?
answer_explanation_text: Directive Principles can be classified into Social and Economic Justice, Ideals of Social Security, and Community Welfare Ideals. Fundamental Rights, on the other hand, are a separate part of the Indian Constitution (Part III) and are enforceable by the courts.

question_text: Which of the following is NOT a difference between fundamental rights and directive principles?
option_1_text: Directives are not enforceable by the court, while fundamental rights are
option_2_text: Directives are positive inducements, while fundamental rights are negative limitations
option_3_text: Directives are implemented by the legislation, while fundamental rights are incorporated in the Constitution
option_4_text: Directives can be declared void by courts, while fundamental rights cannot
answer_explanation_text: The Directive Principles are not so enforceable by the courts nor can the courts declare as void any law which is otherwise valid on the ground that contravenes any of the Directives.

question_text: In which case did the Supreme Court highlight the unenforceable nature of directive principles?
option_2_text: A.B.Soshit Karamchari Sangh vs Union of India (1981)
answer_explanation_text: In this case, the Supreme Court declared that no law could be declared void on the ground of contravening the directive principles.

question_text: Which Amendment Act introduced Article 31C to protect a law seeking to implement a directive under 39 (b)-(c) from being declared ultra vires on the ground of contravening?
answer_explanation_text: The 25th Amendment Act (1971) introduced Article 31C, which sought to protect a law seeking to implement a directive under 39 (b)-(c) from being declared ultra vires on the ground of contravening.

question_text: Which case upheld the validity of the 25th Amendment Act?
option_2_text: A.B.Soshit Karamchari Sangh vs Union of India (1981)
answer_explanation_text: The Kesavanand Bharati case (1973) upheld the validity of the 25th Amendment Act, which introduced Article 31C to protect a law seeking to implement a directive under 39 (b)-(c) from being declared ultra vires on the ground of contravening.

question_text: Which case foiled the attempt to accord primacy to the directives over fundamental rights?
option_2_text: A.B.Soshit Karamchari Sangh vs Union of India (1981)
answer_explanation_text: The Minerva Mills case (1980) struck down the expansion of Article 31C to include any or all of the Directives in Part IV, on the ground that such total exclusion of judicial review would offend the <q>basic structure</q> of the Constitution.

question_text: What is the principle that courts should adopt when a law is challenged as constituting an invasion of the fundamental rights specified in Articles 14, 19, or 31?
answer_explanation_text: The principle of harmonious construction suggests that courts should not entirely ignore the Directive Principles and should instead try to give effect to both fundamental rights and directives as much as possible.

question_text: Which Directive is NOT included in Part IV of the Constitution but is still given attention by courts?
answer_explanation_text: Articles 335, 350A, and 351 are not included in Part IV of the Constitution but are still given attention by courts on the application of the principle that all parts of the Constitution should be read together.

question_text: What term describes the suspension of a session everyday, a few days, or indefinitely, at the discretion of the Speaker?
answer_explanation_text: Adjourn refers to the suspension of a session everyday, a few days, or indefinitely. This is at the discretion of the Speaker.

question_text: Who is appointed as the Speaker Protem when the Lok Sabha is summoned for the first time after the general election?
option_3_text: The senior most member of the Lok Sabha
answer_explanation_text: The President appoints a member of the Lok Sabha as the Speaker Protem (normally the senior most member) when it is summoned for the first time after the general election.

question_text: When can a Half an Hour Discussion be held in the Lok Sabha?
option_2_text: From 5 P.M. to 5.30 P.M. on any day allotted by the Chairman
option_4_text: From 4 P.M. to 4.30 P.M. on any day allotted by the Speaker
answer_explanation_text: A Half an Hour Discussion can be held in the Lok Sabha during the last half-an-hour on (Mon-Wed-Fri).

question_text: What is a motion in parliamentary terms?
option_1_text: A proposal brought before the house for eliciting decision or expressing the opinion of the House
option_2_text: Suspension of a session everyday, a few days or indefinitely
option_3_text: Ending the life of a legislature
answer_explanation_text: A motion is a proposal brought before the house for eliciting decision or expressing the opinion of the House.

question_text: Who was the first opposition leader in India to enjoy the status of a Cabinet Minister?
answer_explanation_text: Y. B. Chavan of the Congress (I) was given the official status of the Leader of the Opposition with the rank of a Cabinet Minister, by the Janata Government headed by Morarji Desai. He was the first opposition leader in the country to enjoy this status.

question_text: Which amendment expanded the scope of the directive principles under Article 31C?
answer_explanation_text: The 42nd Amendment (1976) (section 4) further expanded the scope of the directive principles under Art. 31C. It sought to protect any law implementing any of the directive principles from judicial review on the ground of violating Arts. 14 and 19.

question_text: Which articles of the Constitution are addressed to the State and are non-justiciable?
answer_explanation_text: Articles 335, 350A, and 351 are directives addressed to the State in other parts of the Constitution and are nonjusticiable. They cover facilities for instruction in the mother-tongue at the primary stage of education, the promotion of the Hindi language, and the consideration of claims of members of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in appointments to services and posts.
